lines.text: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: As I took note of the place, it cannot be far where he abides.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: What's to be thought of him? does the rumour hold for true, that he's so full of gold?

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Certain: Alcibiades reports it; Phrynia and Timandra had gold of him: he likewise enriched poor straggling soldiers with great quantity: 'tis said he gave unto his steward a mighty sum.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Then this breaking of his has been but a try for his friends.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Nothing else: you shall see him a palm in Athens again, and flourish with the highest. Therefore 'tis not amiss we tender our loves to him, in this supposed distress of his: it will show honestly in us; and is very likely to load our purposes with what they travail for, if it be a just true report that goes of his having.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: What have you now to present unto him?

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Nothing at this time but my visitation: only I will promise him an excellent piece.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: I must serve him so too, tell him of an intent that's coming toward him.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Good as the best. Promising is the very air o' the time: it opens the eyes of expectation: performance is ever the duller for his act; and, but in the plainer and simpler kind of people, the deed of saying is quite out of use. To promise is most courtly and fashionable: performance is a kind of will or testament which argues a great sickness in his judgment that makes it.
TIMON comes from his cave, behind

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: [Aside]  Excellent workman! thou canst not paint a man so bad as is thyself.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: I am thinking what I shall say I have provided for him: it must be a personating of himself; a satire against the softness of prosperity, with a discovery of the infinite flatteries that follow youth and opulency.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: [Aside]  Must thou needs stand for a villain in thine own work? wilt thou whip thine own faults in other men? Do so, I have gold for thee.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Nay, let's seek him: Then do we sin against our own estate, When we may profit meet, and come too late.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: True; When the day serves, before black-corner'd night, Find what thou want'st by free and offer'd light. Come.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: [Aside]  I'll meet you at the turn. What a god's gold, That he is worshipp'd in a baser temple Than where swine feed! 'Tis thou that rigg'st the bark and plough'st the foam, Settlest admired reverence in a slave: To thee be worship! and thy saints for aye Be crown'd with plagues that thee alone obey! Fit I meet them.
Coming forward

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Hail, worthy Timon!

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Our late noble master!

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Have I once lived to see two honest men?

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Sir, Having often of your open bounty tasted, Hearing you were retired, your friends fall'n off, Whose thankless natures--O abhorred spirits!-- Not all the whips of heaven are large enough: What! to you, Whose star-like nobleness gave life and influence To their whole being! I am rapt and cannot cover The monstrous bulk of this ingratitude With any size of words.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Let it go naked, men may see't the better: You that are honest, by being what you are, Make them best seen and known.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: He and myself Have travail'd in the great shower of your gifts, And sweetly felt it.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Ay, you are honest men.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: We are hither come to offer you our service.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Most honest men! Why, how shall I requite you? Can you eat roots, and drink cold water? no.

lines.speaker: both
lines.text: What we can do, we'll do, to do you service.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Ye're honest men: ye've heard that I have gold; I am sure you have: speak truth; ye're honest men.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: So it is said, my noble lord; but therefore Came not my friend nor I.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Good honest men! Thou draw'st a counterfeit Best in all Athens: thou'rt, indeed, the best; Thou counterfeit'st most lively.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: So, so, my lord.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: E'en so, sir, as I say. And, for thy fiction, Why, thy verse swells with stuff so fine and smooth That thou art even natural in thine art. But, for all this, my honest-natured friends, I must needs say you have a little fault: Marry, 'tis not monstrous in you, neither wish I You take much pains to mend.

lines.speaker: both
lines.text: Beseech your honour To make it known to us.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: You'll take it ill.

lines.speaker: both
lines.text: Most thankfully, my lord.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Will you, indeed?

lines.speaker: both
lines.text: Doubt it not, worthy lord.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: There's never a one of you but trusts a knave, That mightily deceives you.

lines.speaker: both
lines.text: Do we, my lord?

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Ay, and you hear him cog, see him dissemble, Know his gross patchery, love him, feed him, Keep in your bosom: yet remain assured That he's a made-up villain.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: I know none such, my lord.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Nor I.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Look you, I love you well; I'll give you gold, Rid me these villains from your companies: Hang them or stab them, drown them in a draught, Confound them by some course, and come to me, I'll give you gold enough.

lines.speaker: both
lines.text: Name them, my lord, let's know them.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: You that way and you this, but two in company; Each man apart, all single and alone, Yet an arch-villain keeps him company. If where thou art two villains shall not be, Come not near him. If thou wouldst not reside But where one villain is, then him abandon. Hence, pack! there's gold; you came for gold, ye slaves: You have work'd for me; there's payment for you: hence! You are an alchemist; make gold of that. Out, rascal dogs!
To Painter
To Poet
Beats them out, and then retires to his cave
Enter FLAVIUS and two Senators

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: It is in vain that you would speak with Timon; For he is set so only to himself That nothing but himself which looks like man Is friendly with him.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Bring us to his cave: It is our part and promise to the Athenians To speak with Timon.

lines.speaker: second senator
lines.text: At all times alike Men are not still the same: 'twas time and griefs That framed him thus: time, with his fairer hand, Offering the fortunes of his former days, The former man may make him. Bring us to him, And chance it as it may.

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: Here is his cave. Peace and content be here! Lord Timon! Timon! Look out, and speak to friends: the Athenians, By two of their most reverend senate, greet thee: Speak to them, noble Timon.
TIMON comes from his cave

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Thou sun, that comfort'st, burn! Speak, and be hang'd: For each true word, a blister! and each false Be as cauterizing to the root o' the tongue, Consuming it with speaking!

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Worthy Timon,--

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Of none but such as you, and you of Timon.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: The senators of Athens greet thee, Timon.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: I thank them; and would send them back the plague, Could I but catch it for them.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: O, forget What we are sorry for ourselves in thee. The senators with one consent of love Entreat thee back to Athens; who have thought On special dignities, which vacant lie For thy best use and wearing.

lines.speaker: second senator
lines.text: They confess Toward thee forgetfulness too general, gross: Which now the public body, which doth seldom Play the recanter, feeling in itself A lack of Timon's aid, hath sense withal Of its own fail, restraining aid to Timon; And send forth us, to make their sorrow'd render, Together with a recompense more fruitful Than their offence can weigh down by the dram; Ay, even such heaps and sums of love and wealth As shall to thee blot out what wrongs were theirs And write in thee the figures of their love, Ever to read them thine.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: You witch me in it; Surprise me to the very brink of tears: Lend me a fool's heart and a woman's eyes, And I'll beweep these comforts, worthy senators.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Therefore, so please thee to return with us And of our Athens, thine and ours, to take The captainship, thou shalt be met with thanks, Allow'd with absolute power and thy good name Live with authority: so soon we shall drive back Of Alcibiades the approaches wild, Who, like a boar too savage, doth root up His country's peace.

lines.speaker: second senator
lines.text: And shakes his threatening sword Against the walls of Athens.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Therefore, Timon,--

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Well, sir, I will; therefore, I will, sir; thus: If Alcibiades kill my countrymen, Let Alcibiades know this of Timon, That Timon cares not. But if be sack fair Athens, And take our goodly aged men by the beards, Giving our holy virgins to the stain Of contumelious, beastly, mad-brain'd war, Then let him know, and tell him Timon speaks it, In pity of our aged and our youth, I cannot choose but tell him, that I care not, And let him take't at worst; for their knives care not, While you have throats to answer: for myself, There's not a whittle in the unruly camp But I do prize it at my love before The reverend'st throat in Athens. So I leave you To the protection of the prosperous gods, As thieves to keepers.

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: Stay not, all's in vain.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Why, I was writing of my epitaph; it will be seen to-morrow: my long sickness Of health and living now begins to mend, And nothing brings me all things. Go, live still; Be Alcibiades your plague, you his, And last so long enough!

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: We speak in vain.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: But yet I love my country, and am not One that rejoices in the common wreck, As common bruit doth put it.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: That's well spoke.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Commend me to my loving countrymen,--

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: These words become your lips as they pass thorough them.

lines.speaker: second senator
lines.text: And enter in our ears like great triumphers In their applauding gates.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Commend me to them, And tell them that, to ease them of their griefs, Their fears of hostile strokes, their aches, losses, Their pangs of love, with other incident throes That nature's fragile vessel doth sustain In life's uncertain voyage, I will some kindness do them: I'll teach them to prevent wild Alcibiades' wrath.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: I like this well; he will return again.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: I have a tree, which grows here in my close, That mine own use invites me to cut down, And shortly must I fell it: tell my friends, Tell Athens, in the sequence of degree From high to low throughout, that whoso please To stop affliction, let him take his haste, Come hither, ere my tree hath felt the axe, And hang himself. I pray you, do my greeting.

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: Trouble him no further; thus you still shall find him.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Come not to me again: but say to Athens, Timon hath made his everlasting mansion Upon the beached verge of the salt flood; Who once a day with his embossed froth The turbulent surge shall cover: thither come, And let my grave-stone be your oracle. Lips, let sour words go by and language end: What is amiss plague and infection mend! Graves only be men's works and death their gain! Sun, hide thy beams! Timon hath done his reign.
Retires to his cave

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: His discontents are unremoveably Coupled to nature.

lines.speaker: second senator
lines.text: Our hope in him is dead: let us return, And strain what other means is left unto us In our dear peril.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: It requires swift foot. Thou hast painfully discover'd: are his files As full as thy report?
Exeunt
